text: on Monday the u.s. recertified that Iran
was complying with the terms of the
nuclear deal but as the u.s. itself
complying listen closely to what White
House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders
said in her briefing just a few days
earlier in his discussions with more
than a dozen foreign leaders he
underscored the need for nations to join
together to strip terrorists of their
funding territory an ideological support
and to stop doing business with nations
that sponsor terrorism especially Iran
in this one brief statement following
the g20 meeting Huckabee Sanders may
have openly admitted that the United
States is for the first time not
complying with its agreement with Iran
and other Western nations that agreement
says the US can't pursue a policy that
adversely affects the normalization of
trade and economic relations with Iran
Iran is arguing that the u.s. is not
complying with that agreement when the
White House made an announcement a
couple of days ago that President Trump
used his presence in Hamburg during the
g20 meeting in order to dissuade leaders
other from other countries to engage in
business with Iran that is a violation
of not the spirit but of the letter of
the jcpoa of the nuclear deal the
Russians which often aligned with Iran
have weighed in too this is a situation
when the u.s. action or lack of action
contradicts the very essence of the
document and thus is incompatible with
the letter and the spirit of the jcpoa
the nuclear deal has paved the way for
some commerce to resume between Iran and
the West us-based Boeing signed a three
billion dollar deal with the country's
Athlon Airlines this spring and in June
Iran's oil exports to the West at its
highest level since the lifting of
sanctions but President Trump spent the
campaign season rallying against the
Iranian nuclear agreement never ever
ever in my life have I seen any
transaction so incompetently negotiated
as our deal with Iran and so he's looked
for new ways to challenge Iran by
imposing sanctions that would target not
those companies covered under the
nuclear agreement
but instead those involved in cyber and
military programs and things the US says
contribute to Iran's exporting of
terrorism the question is whether it's
bad-mouthing Iran at the g20 was aimed
at the business entities protected under
the nuclear deal articles of the jcpoa
do not include a general exception for
terrorism or anything else so to try to
persuade other world leaders not to do
business with Iran generally does seem
to be a pretty clear instance of
non-compliance with paragraph 29 of the
jcpoa if the u.s. isn't in compliance
there likely won't be any material
penalties immediately but it could for
future negotiations between the u.s. and
Iran if not ultimately kill the nuclear
deal altogether
[Music]
